visibility_factors: light freezing rain around midnight (ice/glaze risk)
areas of very low visibility reported at times (0–1 mi)
late-night freezing fog potential (esp. toward 11 PM)

alert_summary.description: In effect Thu Jan 22 until 7:00 PM EST. Snow up to 1–2 inches with gusts to ~35 mph; slick roads and rapidly changing visibility in lake-effect bands.
Begins 1:00 AM Fri Jan 23 through 10:00 AM Sat Jan 24. Wind chills down to ~-25°F possible; frostbite risk on exposed skin.
Bitter cold increases risk of river ice jams through Sun Jan 25; not a direct school-transport hazard but signals sustained extreme cold.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Friday 2026-01-23 in Rockford, the primary school-impacting hazard is not snowfall amount (only ~0.2–0.3" expected, with brief light snow 1–3 AM), but a short window of light freezing rain near midnight followed by a rapid temperature drop into subzero/teens-below-zero air. Any glaze that forms on untreated roads/bridges could flash-freeze and persist through the morning commute. Winds remain breezy (~13–19 mph) with very dangerous wind chills (around -20°F to -30°F range by early morning), matching the Cold Weather Advisory timing (1 AM Fri onward). Visibility improves to ~6 miles by daybreak, but there are signals for intermittent near-zero visibility periods overnight and possible freezing fog late evening. Net: snow-only closure is unlikely in Michigan given low accumulation and precipitation ending well before/around 4 AM, but an ice-driven delay/closure is plausible if freezing rain/glaze verifies and road crews can’t fully mitigate before buses run.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Arctic outbreak with little new snowfall: single-digit/near-zero daytime temps, sub-zero wind chills during the morning commute, but only light/flurry-type snow after an earlier burst. In West Michigan this more often produces 'cold day' operations (extra bundling, indoor recess) rather than a closure unless wind chills cross common policy thresholds or transportation issues emerge.

Light snow plus strong cold advection behind a system: a quick overnight coating (≤1 inch) followed by clearing, falling temps, and gusty NW winds. Historically, closures are more likely when the light snow/ice coincides with peak commute and creates widespread glaze on untreated roads/bridges—especially for rural bus routes—than from the snow amount itself.

Marginal freezing-rain window before a deep freeze: brief freezing rain around/just after midnight followed by temperatures staying well below 32°F all day. This pattern can create persistent slick spots (bridges, overpasses, shaded roads) that do not improve, but the outcome depends heavily on how much glaze actually forms and whether crews can treat before the morning routes.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in Rockford (Kent County, west of Grand Rapids) is climatologically one of the coldest parts of winter, so cold mornings are not unusual. However, district-wide closures in Michigan are more commonly driven by high-impact hazards (ice storms, true blizzard conditions, or extreme wind chills) than by light snowfall totals.
unusual_factors: Forecast temperatures are exceptionally low (high near 2°F, low near -13°F), increasing risk of frostbite and operational stress (bus reliability, student exposure at stops).
Wind chills are forecast to be near or below -20°F during the early morning hours, aligning with the typical decision window for schools.
A brief freezing-rain signal around midnight could create isolated glaze before temperatures crash, potentially locking in slick conditions through the morning.
Patchy visibility drops are possible (notably around 00:00–01:00 and again late evening with freezing fog), though the main school commute window appears mostly dry/clear of active precip.

local_microclimates: West Michigan lake-effect variability: bands can produce localized slick roads even when city totals are low; a few miles can make a big difference.
River valleys/low-lying spots around the Rogue River can hold colder air and develop localized fog/black-ice issues, especially after earlier moisture.
Shaded neighborhood roads and untreated rural connectors can remain icy all day when temperatures stay near/under 0–5°F.
infrastructure_considerations: Kent County and the Rockford area generally have solid plowing/pretreatment capability, reducing closure odds when snowfall is light.
Bus-stop exposure becomes a bigger issue in extreme wind chills; even if roads are passable, districts may delay/close to reduce time students wait outside.
Bridges/overpasses and secondary roads are the main risk points if any freezing rain or earlier blowing snow leaves a thin, hard-to-treat glaze.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest elevation changes won’t drive major snowfall differences, but they can contribute to localized drifting and slick hills on secondary roads when winds are NW 10–20 mph.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall closure risk is driven far more by extreme cold/wind chill and any residual icing than by snow amount (forecast snow ~0.2 inches). For Friday 2026-01-23, the forecast favors very cold, mostly dry daytime conditions with only light overnight wintry precip. In Michigan, that usually points to 'school open' or at most a delay, unless (a) wind chills during the 6–9 AM window meet local closure thresholds, or (b) the midnight freezing-rain period produces enough glaze to create widespread slick travel on untreated routes. Confidence is medium that snow alone will not trigger a closure; confidence is lower on the ice impact because small changes in glaze/road treatment can swing decisions.

safety_recommendations: Primary risk is a brief freezing-rain/snow burst overnight (roughly 12–4 AM) followed by a sharp temperature drop; expect refreeze/black ice on untreated surfaces (bridges, ramps, subdivision streets) into the 6–8 AM window.

Assume main corridors and state/county primaries are plowed/treated by morning in West Michigan; the bigger issue for buses is slick neighborhood pickup roads, rural connectors, and school lot/loop areas that may remain hard-packed or icy.

Have transportation staff do an early route check focusing on bridges/overpasses, shaded curves, and stop-sign intersections; be prepared for spot delays on secondary roads even if highways look fine.
Increase traction control: slower bus speeds, larger following distances, and avoid hard braking at stops; consider consolidating stops if standard practice allows to reduce hill/turn exposure.
Given wind chills near -20 to -25°F during the morning commute, prioritize student cold exposure mitigation (shorter outdoor waits, warmed buses, door-to-door timing, monitor for late buses).

Parking lots/sidewalks: prioritize treatment of entrances, crosswalks, and staff lots before arrival; blowing/drifting is not a major issue Friday, but any thin glaze will be persistent because temps stay well below freezing all day.

Freezing fog late evening (after school hours) may reduce visibility for activities/late routes; plan earlier dismissals for evening events or ensure extra lighting/spotters in lots if activities proceed.

county_roads.estimated_clear_time: Primary county arterials and main connectors improving through the night; most bus-route arterials likely 'mostly passable but slick' by ~06:30–08:00 on 2026-01-23; secondary/residential later in the morning.

clearing_timeline.snow_end_time: Light snow/freezing precip risk mainly overnight, with the more impactful travel hazard shifting to refreeze/packed snow/ice by daybreak on 2026-01-23.

County/local roads (especially untreated/low-traffic): likely packed snow and/or glaze ice; drifting not the main issue but traction will be limited and stopping distances long.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: For Rockford (Kent County) on Friday 2026-01-23, the bigger operational problem is not snowfall amount (~0.6 cm forecast) but extreme cold (wind chills near/below -25F) causing de-icer effectiveness to drop and allowing roads to stay icy/packed. Expect MDOT trunklines (US-131/I-96/M routes) to be the most consistently treated overnight, while many county/local roads may remain slick at 6:30 AM. This setup is more consistent with a DELAY risk than a full snow day solely from accumulation, but closures become more likely if early-morning ice/glaze develops or if spotty whiteout/squalls redevelop unexpectedly.

powerGrid.overall_grid_assessment: For Friday 2026-01-23 in Rockford (Kent County), the primary operational risk for K-12 is not widespread grid failure but *extreme cold* (high ~2°F, low ~-13°F with wind chills potentially near -25°F or colder). However, the combination of extreme cold + early-morning light freezing rain/snow creates an elevated risk of *scattered*, localized outages and potential heating-related building issues (boilers/controls, frozen pipes) even if power remains on. Snow-day likelihood from precipitation alone looks low (light amounts), but cold-exposure logistics (bus stops, student safety, diesel start issues) may drive delays/closures depending on district wind-chill policy.

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement: All experts agree snowfall amount is not the issue; the hazards are (a) extreme wind chills and (b) flash-freeze/black ice from a brief freezing-rain/mix window. Roads likely ‘passable but slick’ on main routes; neighborhoods/local streets are the concern.
2) Disagreement: The biggest conflict was wind chill cross-source; web verification resolved it—Weather.com capture was date-mismatched, while NWS point forecast supports wind chills as low as -28°F. Another tension: corridor article mentioning 1–4" along/west of US-131 vs API ~0.2"; this appears corridor-wide and not Rockford-specific, so I treat it as a modest upside-risk rather than the base case.
3) Plow timing math: Worst precip/icing window ~00:00–04:00. From ~04:00 to 07:40 start time is ~3.5 hours. That’s enough for trunklines/arterials to be improved, but not enough (given night staffing + subzero temps reducing salt effectiveness) to expect residential/bus-stop streets to be reliably good by first pickup.
4) Ice? Yes—credible light freezing rain/drizzle near midnight. Even a light glaze matters because temps plunge and persist below freezing all day.
5) Neighboring districts: News intel could not confirm any Friday closures/delays posted yet across Forest Hills, GRPS, Kentwood, Northview, Cedar Springs, Godwin Heights, Comstock Park.
6) Power outages: No confirmed significant outage clusters; tool could not verify interactive-map details. I do not add an outage boost.
7) Wind chill verification: Confirmed by both WeatherAPI hourly and NWS point forecast (≤ -20°F, potentially near -28°F).
8) What would make me wrong? (a) If roads are better than expected on local streets by 6–7 AM (aggressive sanding/pretreatment + little/no glaze), schools likely open (possibly with indoor recess). (b) If corridor lake-effect produces closer to 1–4" locally OR glaze is more widespread than expected, closure probability rises sharply.

Weighting (per directive): Meteorology 25% (supports extreme cold + small precip), Safety 20% (moderate road risk but not systemic), History 15% (borderline; delays more common), News 15% (no neighbor closures yet—downward pressure), Infrastructure 10% (local roads likely still slick at 6:30—upward pressure), Power 10% (no strong outage signal—neutral), Web verification 5% (confirms ≤ -20°F—upward pressure).

Outcome: With confirmed ≤ -20°F wind chills (a strong closure trigger) but no confirmed neighbor closures and only light precip totals, I land at 45% for a full closure. I would rate a 2-hour delay as slightly more likely than a full closure given expected marginal neighborhood-road conditions and student exposure risk.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: 2-hour delay instead of full closure (most likely alternative)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Allows daylight/crew ramp-up to improve local streets/parking lots and reduces time students wait outside in dangerous wind chills.
Requires minimal glaze/black ice plus adequate sanding on neighborhood bus routes; expect cold-weather operations (indoor recess, warming plans).

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Full closure becomes likely if heavier lake-effect/ice verifies locally (near the 1–4" corridor or more glaze)
alternative_scenarios.impact: More widespread slick travel and route failures; closure probability would jump into ~60–75% if confirmed by early AM road checks and neighbor announcements.

for_schools: Plan for a closure/delay decision driven by wind chill + bus-stop exposure; if operating, implement a ‘minimal outdoor wait’ plan and allow late arrivals without penalty.
Run early route checks (focus: neighborhood streets, hills/curves, bridges/overpasses, stop-sign intersections) and prioritize sanding of known trouble spots near schools.
If open, consider holding buses briefly at warm staging areas to reduce student wait time and coordinate extra supervision at stops.
for_residents: Assume black ice on low-traffic roads/driveways; slow down and increase following distance, especially 05:30–09:00.
Limit time outside; cover exposed skin (wind chills can cause frostbite quickly).
Check district alerts early (5–7 AM) and prepare for a likely delay scenario.
for_authorities: Prioritize sanding (not just salting) on bridges/ramps/intersections and neighborhood collector roads before 6:30 AM given subzero effectiveness limits.
Coordinate rapid situational reports to schools (road commission + law enforcement) on any crash clusters or untreated slick corridors.
If possible, provide public updates on the US-131 corridor lake-effect/visibility variability and spotty glaze reports before commute peak.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, this is a **low-snow / high-cold** day. With only a light coating expected, most Michigan districts stay open if roads are treated. The closure risk comes from (1) **wind chills in the -20s** right at bus-stop time and (2) **flash-freeze/black-ice potential** after a short freezing-rain window around midnight. Those two hazards raise the odds into the ‘meaningful but not favored’ range. I land at **35%** for a full snow day (closure), with a higher implied chance of a **delay** than a closure, given precip ends early and winds/visibility are not extreme during the commute.
keyFactors: **Extreme cold during decision window (Fri 1/23, ~6–9 AM):** temps around -3°F to -1°F with **wind chills roughly -20°F to -23°F** (Cold Weather Advisory timing begins 1 AM Fri). This is the *only* meteorological factor that could plausibly drive a closure by itself (student exposure at stops, mechanical/bus reliability).

**Brief icing window before the deep freeze:** light freezing rain around **midnight** (00:00) with precip continuing as light snow 1–3 AM. Even a thin glaze, followed by temps plunging well below 0°F, can create **persistent black ice** on bridges/ramps/untreated neighborhood roads through the morning commute.
**Snow amounts are minor:** forecast totals ~0.23" snow for Fri with precip largely ending well before school start, which strongly argues *against* a classic “snow day” based on accumulation.

**Winds are not blizzard-level:** sustained ~13–16 mph, gusts ~20–30 mph overnight—enough to worsen wind chill and create localized blowing/drifting from existing snow, but not a stand-alone closure driver.

**Visibility risk is episodic, not sustained:** near-zero vis is indicated at a few overnight hours (and late-night freezing fog), but the core commute period looks mostly dry with improved vis—so visibility is more of a “spot hazard” than district-wide shutdown signal.

positions.rationale:
From a historical decision-pattern standpoint, the forecast reads like a *borderline cold/ice operational day* rather than a classic “snow day”: expected new snow on Friday is very small (~0.2–0.3"), and the worst precip is overnight. That typically means school stays open.

However, the combination of (1) a brief freezing-rain window near midnight, (2) a rapid crash into subzero air, and (3) very low morning wind chills increases the rate of closures vs. a normal “cold but dry” day. The peer inputs (Safety/Infrastructure/Meteorology) all raise credible flags that, historically, are the exact ones that occasionally flip districts to a closure even without heavy snow.

Net: I’m placing this below 50% because the *storm-timing and accumulation* don’t historically support widespread closures in this part of Michigan, but I’m materially above a “low” number because wind chill policy and refreeze risk can drive decisions disproportionately in arctic-outbreak situations.
keyFactors: **Historical pattern match (arctic outbreak, little new snow):** In West Michigan, very cold days with minimal new snowfall more often stay *open* (maybe indoor recess/modified ops) unless there’s a clear transportation trigger (ice/visibility) or an explicit wind-chill policy threshold reached during the decision window.

**Timing matters:** The higher-impact precip signal is **00:00–04:00** (light freezing rain + light snow bursts). By **06:00–09:00** (bus window), the forecast turns mostly dry with improving visibility. Historically, that reduces *full-closure* frequency versus storms peaking at commute.

**But “ice + deep freeze” can outperform snowfall totals:** Even a thin glaze just after midnight can become “locked in” because temps plunge and stay well below freezing all day, making improvement slow—this is the main historical route to a closure *despite* low snow totals.

**Extreme wind chills are close to common closure triggers:** Forecast “feels like” around **-20°F to -30°F** during the morning window (and a Cold Weather Advisory calling out wind chills as low as **-25°F**) increases the chance of a delay/closure on exposure grounds alone, especially for elementary bus stops.

**Local capacity reduces closure odds (historically):** Kent County/Rockford generally has strong road treatment/plowing capability, which historically converts many borderline events into “open” or “delay,” unless icing is widespread or temps make treatment ineffective.

positions.rationale: From a safety perspective, Friday 2026-01-23 presents a credible (but not dominant) snow-day risk. Accumulating snow is minimal and ends well before the commute, which usually argues for school operating. However, the combination of (1) a short freezing-rain/mix burst around midnight and (2) a rapid drop to near/under 0°F with wind chills in the -20s during the decision window creates a disproportionate hazard: thin glaze + refreeze = persistent black ice on secondary roads and school-property surfaces. Even if main roads are treated, the safety-critical points for school transport are neighborhood pickups, intersections, bridges, and lots—exactly where thin ice causes crashes and delays. Extreme cold also elevates student exposure risk at stops if transportation runs behind. Net: I land in the upper ‘delay-likely / closure-possible’ range, with closure probability below 50% but meaningfully elevated versus a typical light-snow day.
keyFactors: Primary closure driver is **extreme cold exposure**, not snow totals: temps near 0°F at/after daybreak with **wind chills roughly -20°F to -25°F** during the decision window (about 6–9 AM).
**Ice risk is the swing factor**: a brief **freezing-rain / mixed precip** window around **12–1 AM** followed by a hard freeze can lock in **black ice** on untreated surfaces through the AM commute.

Road network likely splits: **trunklines/arterials** improve overnight, but **neighborhood pickup roads, shaded curves, bridges/overpasses, and school lots** can remain slick because treatment effectiveness drops sharply in very low temps.

Operational safety concerns beyond roads: **students waiting at stops** in dangerous wind chills (risk increases if buses run late due to slick spots), and possible **diesel/bus reliability** issues in subzero conditions.
Snow amount itself is low (~0.2–0.3"), so a full closure is less likely than a **delay**, unless wind-chill policy or icing verifies as more widespread than forecast.

positions.rationale: From a news/behavioral standpoint, this looks like a day where districts *consider* action because the hazard is student exposure (wind chills in the -20s) plus potential overnight glazing—not because of heavy snow. That pattern frequently yields a **delay** more than a full closure in West Michigan, especially if main roads are treated by morning. The lack of an early official closure signal (and minimal outage issues) keeps me below 50%, but the NWS advisory timing + wind chill magnitude keeps me well above a “routine cold day.” Net: I’m at **38%** for a snow day (closure), with a meaningful tail risk for a 2-hour delay instead of closure.
keyFactors: **Primary closure driver is extreme cold/wind chill, not snow.** NWS Cold Weather Advisory runs **Fri 1:00 AM–Sat 10:00 AM** with wind chills **as low as -25°F**, and the hourly forecast has “feels like” around **-20°F to -23°F** during typical decision/commute hours (6–9 AM).

**Mixed-precip “gotcha” risk overnight:** a short window of **light freezing rain near midnight** plus light snow (1–3 AM) followed by a sharp temp drop increases odds of **flash-freeze/black ice** on bridges, ramps, and neighborhood roads—even if total snow is only ~0.2–0.3".

**News/ops signals are supportive but not decisive:** local media are already messaging dangerous cold, and Kent County road-crew messaging suggests active winter conditions; however, those do not guarantee a school closure on their own.

**No strong “pre-closure” signal yet from the district:** Rockford Public Schools has **no prominent Fri 1/23 closure/delay post** in the provided crawl; neighboring Forest Hills only canceled **Thu 1/22 after-school activities**, which is a weaker signal for a Friday full closure.
**Power-grid appears stable (very low outages),** reducing odds of a closure driven by facility/power loss rather than travel/cold exposure.

debates.topic: Your historical pattern rates (0.25–0.40) are reasonable, but I’d weight them toward the lower end unless you can cite a *local* wind-chill closure threshold for Rockford (many districts do not auto-close at -20°F wind chills, reserving closures for -25°F to -35°F or for transportation failure). Without that policy detail, history may be overpredicting closures from cold alone.
debates.challenge: Your historical pattern rates (0.25–0.40) are reasonable, but I’d weight them toward the lower end unless you can cite a *local* wind-chill closure threshold for Rockford (many districts do not auto-close at -20°F wind chills, reserving closures for -25°F to -35°F or for transportation failure). Without that policy detail, history may be overpredicting closures from cold alone.

debates.topic: You rate ice-formation risk as “high,” but the forecast liquid equivalent/icing signal is **small** (brief light freezing rain, then light snow). Can you clarify whether your score assumes untreated conditions everywhere, or whether you’re incorporating Kent County pretreatment capacity and the fact that precip largely ends before commute? This matters because thin glaze is often mitigated on primaries but persists on residential/bus routes—driving *delay* more than *closure*.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Meteorologically, this is a **low-snow / high-cold** day. With only a light coating expected, most Michigan districts stay open if roads are treated. The closure risk comes from (1) **wind chills in the -20s** right at bus-stop time and (2) **flash-freeze/black-ice potential** after a short freezing-rain window around midnight. Those two hazards raise the odds into the ‘meaningful but not favored’ range. I land at **35%** for a full snow day (closure), with a higher implied chance of a **delay** than a closure, given precip ends early and winds/visibility are not extreme during the commute.

From a historical decision-pattern standpoint, the forecast reads like a *borderline cold/ice operational day* rather than a classic “snow day”: expected new snow on Friday is very small (~0.2–0.3"), and the worst precip is overnight. That typically means school stays open.

However, the combination of (1) a brief freezing-rain window near midnight, (2) a rapid crash into subzero air, and (3) very low morning wind chills increases the rate of closures vs. a normal “cold but dry” day. The peer inputs (Safety/Infrastructure/Meteorology) all raise credible flags that, historically, are the exact ones that occasionally flip districts to a closure even without heavy snow.

Net: I’m placing this below 50% because the *storm-timing and accumulation* don’t historically support widespread closures in this part of Michigan, but I’m materially above a “low” number because wind chill policy and refreeze risk can drive decisions disproportionately in arctic-outbreak situations.

From a safety perspective, Friday 2026-01-23 presents a credible (but not dominant) snow-day risk. Accumulating snow is minimal and ends well before the commute, which usually argues for school operating. However, the combination of (1) a short freezing-rain/mix burst around midnight and (2) a rapid drop to near/under 0°F with wind chills in the -20s during the decision window creates a disproportionate hazard: thin glaze + refreeze = persistent black ice on secondary roads and school-property surfaces. Even if main roads are treated, the safety-critical points for school transport are neighborhood pickups, intersections, bridges, and lots—exactly where thin ice causes crashes and delays. Extreme cold also elevates student exposure risk at stops if transportation runs behind. Net: I land in the upper ‘delay-likely / closure-possible’ range, with closure probability below 50% but meaningfully elevated versus a typical light-snow day.

From a news/behavioral standpoint, this looks like a day where districts *consider* action because the hazard is student exposure (wind chills in the -20s) plus potential overnight glazing—not because of heavy snow. That pattern frequently yields a **delay** more than a full closure in West Michigan, especially if main roads are treated by morning. The lack of an early official closure signal (and minimal outage issues) keeps me below 50%, but the NWS advisory timing + wind chill magnitude keeps me well above a “routine cold day.” Net: I’m at **38%** for a snow day (closure), with a meaningful tail risk for a 2-hour delay instead of closure.

Without that policy detail, history may be overpredicting closures from cold alone.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 22 at 11:14AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clare, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Gratiot, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Isabella, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Lake, MI; Mason, MI; Mecosta, MI; Montcalm, MI; Muskegon, MI; Newaygo, MI; Oceana, MI; Osceola, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Bitterly cold temperatures moving into Michigan over the next few
days will increase the risk of ice jams on rivers. While many
locations have already frozen over, ongoing ice growth will continue
to increase in any open water areas.

These temperatures have not been seen for many years in West
Michigan, which means that some areas that don't typically
experience river ice jams may have issues this year. Ice jams can
result in water levels rising much more quickly than usual, which
can catch people off guard. Anyone living or working near rivers in
West Michigan should prepare now for potential river ice and rising
water levels.

While temperatures warm up a bit early next week, this overall cold
weather pattern will continue through at least next week, which will
keep ice locked in place on the rivers.


You can always find the latest river level information at water.noaa.
gov

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 22 at 10:50AM EST until January 22 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch or two.
Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan
on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact
the Thursday evening commute.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 22 at 10:50AM EST until January 24 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 25 below expected.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...From 1 AM Friday to 10 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 below zero
could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves.

Keep pets indoors as much as possible.

Make frequent checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure
portable heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills
inside.
